results.title: Where she belongs...
results.creator_credit: Nicole Hucks, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nikki Butler pays tribute to her Nana, a strong, knowledgeable Aboriginal women. Despite being a part of the Stolen Generation and growing up away from her land, Nana has taught Butler so much about her heritage, culture and land. Butler hopes to be with her when Nana does finally return home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicole Hucks, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Ngi bali, hello welcome
results.creator_credit: Jade Colgan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jade Colgan may not be easily recognised as Indigenous in Melbourne but she feels connected to her homeland up the Darling River, where she spends her family holidays. Her time there has taught Colgan that life is about laughing, learning and doing the things that help you find out who you are.

results.title: My Nan
results.creator_credit: Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Elsie Jones was a respected Aboriginal elder and a lovely woman, the kind of lady you never forget. She died when Teialah Mason was six but has left an indelible impression on her and has inspired in Mason pride in her heritage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My island home
results.creator_credit: Lionel Austin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Lionel Austin, has lived in Melbourne all his life, his demons reside there. Where he finds his peace is Fraser Island, a natual wonderland and, ultimately, where his heart resides.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lionel Austin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My Grandfather TL
results.creator_credit: Simone Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Simone Andy’s fondly recalls her great-grandfather Thomas Lyon or, as he was known, Grandfather TL. A proud, strong Aboriginal man, Grandfather TL fought in the war and finally recieved his medals in 1996. His death in 1989 set Andy on a journey to find out more about her beloved great-grandfather and, ultimately, to find out who she is.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Simone Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Between generations
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Rebecca Phillips considers how much has changed since her mother went to school. Perhaps she could now sit at the tables and play with the other kids, but she still felt ostracised for being different. Despite this, she has learnt to be proud of her heritage and found her place in the world.

results.title: Fishtank
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
A high-rise flat in the U.K. Midlands. Ray is the father who drinks, Liz the mother, Jason the brother. There are some animals and the brother kills flies. The older brother films them with his handycam - intently observing whatever is going on.

In 1996 Richard Billingham’s ‘Ray’s a Laugh’ was hailed as the photo book of the decade. His photographs were one of the talking points of ‘Sensation’. Billingham has now made ‘Fishtank’, a commission for television by Artangel in collaboration with film-maker Adam Curtis and Illuminations TV for BBC2’s acclaimed TV series. The ‘video verite’ of Fishtank is contained within the compressed space/fishtank of the flat. Sometimes they talk, sometimes they argue. Billingham’s film registers the emotional temperature of this space and the family who live there with a closeness that transcends camera conventions. Like the paintings of Lucian Freud, Billingham crafts a terrible beauty from the landscape of family life and its patterns of pathos, despair and hope.

results.title: Not fourteen again
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Jenny Day, Big Picture Company and Spirited Films
results.brief_description: Not fourteen again is the fourth in a series of film documentaries about the social histories of three working class women. The series examines the womens’ achievements, failures and changing attitudes. In this episode the women are mothers and wives in their thirties. Their teenage daughters, who are now at the age their mothers were when the series began are documented with equal importance. “Not fourteen again” presents a personal account of three young women and Armstrong, who is by now an old friend, builds a fascinating document.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Jenny Day, Big Picture Company and Spirited Films

results.title: Eora corroboree
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Michael Le Moignan, Yuri Sokol and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
For 40,000 years, the Aboriginal people of Australia had a rich and diverse culture, which sprang from and reflected their way of life and beliefs. Their culture was not written, but spoken, sung and performed. Since the coming of white man their culture has very nearly been destroyed. Aboriginal playwright, screenwriter and director Bob Merritt believes that a resurgence of Aboriginal culture is possible and in 1984 set up the Eora Centre for the Visual and Performing Arts in Redfern to offer young Aboriginals a comprehensive education in their traditional arts. Looks at the role of the Eora Centre and interviews some of its teachers and students.
